title: The Hook Matters
content:
No, I didn’t send this on the wrong day. I know it’s Tuesday. The whole point of the subject line was to make you open this email.

And you did.

That’s today’s lesson. I love studying subject lines and understanding what people actually click on. Headlines matter more than most people think.

It’s the same reason news headlines are always so catchy. They’re written to pull you in—even if the story has nothing to do with your interests, you still read it because the headline grabbed you.

That’s what I try to do with everything I make. And you should too.

Bring the user in. Keep them around. Guide their attention.

This applies anywhere you post. The hook is the most important part. If you can’t get someone to stop scrolling and follow you for a moment, you can’t do much else.

So work on your hook. Work on getting eyeballs on your stuff. Share every day. Stay visible.

If you do that, you’ll eventually see success.

title: The Truth About ‘Starting From Nothing’
content:
I often wonder what really makes someone successful. How did they actually get there?

Most of the time, the people you see winning had help—real help. And there’s nothing wrong with that. It’s just interesting to notice.

You know the stories: “We started building this, and instead of taking VC money, we asked friends and family and raised $100k.”

$100k?
Holy shit.

I grew up middle class, but I never had friends or family who could pull together that kind of cash. And I’m not mad at anyone for having that advantage. They still had to execute. They still had to build something real.

But it hits you a little differently. You think, “I can do this,” and then you learn they had a six-figure head start.

$100k gets you marketing. It gets you a teammate. It buys you time. It even gets you a meeting with someone who changes everything.

So I’m always hesitant when someone says, “I started from nothing.” Sure—they started at zero. But three months later, they scaled with a friends-and-family raise that most people never have access to.

What am I really trying to say? In the end, the advantage that matters most isn’t money—it’s marketing. If you can market better, faster, and smarter than your competition… you win.

title: Don't Quit—Pivot
content:
Some days you don’t want to keep going. You want to pause for a day or a week and promise yourself you’ll pick it back up later.

The problem is, when you actually stop, coming back gets harder. Maybe you’re different—personally, I’m not. When I pause, momentum dies.

Tonight was the first night I didn’t know what I wanted to write about. Not because I ran out of ideas, but because I wasn’t sure which idea mattered today.

Everyone works differently, and I’m no exception. But here’s one thing I’ve learned: if you don’t speak up, if you don’t share what’s going on, two things happen—people don’t get to know you, and you don’t grow yourself.

Humans crave connection. That’s why so many solopreneurs burn out. The social side disappears. Even people earning serious money feel it—they’re spending ten hours a day fixing bugs, shipping features, competing with companies far bigger than them.

I’ve been there… and not even at a high level. It stressed me out. Writing this newsletter feels different. It’s organic. It’s honest. It’s me learning in real time. I don’t feel like quitting, because I finally found my lane.

You don’t need to be the biggest player to make the money you want. You just need to stay consistent and keep showing up.

This week I gained 28 subscribers—four per day. I’m completely fine with that because one day, I know it’ll be 28 per hour. It might take years. I’m not stopping.

So if you feel like quitting, maybe you don’t need to quit—you need to pivot. Even if you shut down your current business, you can redirect that energy into something new.

The people who adapt survive. AI is here. Learn it. Pivot with it. Keep moving.

title: Push Through the Burnout — Marketing Matters
content:
I'm tired, but not in the sense you might think.

You see, I have been doing side hustles for many years, and one thing always happened: I get burnt out or bored with the idea, then move on.

I mentioned this in a previous issue, but it’s such a big thing for me I’d like to re-explain it.

I get tired of doing the same thing over and over again, and honestly, most people do.

But as I said yesterday, this is where legends are made.

If you are tired, you have that much more reason to push through.

My normal routine:

  • Find a killer idea
  • Build a Micro SaaS for it
  • Sell it (one-time fee, but it can be anything)
  • Market it

The marketing is when I get bored and feel done—not sure what to write, not sure what meme will pop off.

Most people do this now, and with AI, it’s even faster to get to MVP.

Let me say this: you don’t need a big following. Even my X account only has 6k users.

What you need is a niche you want to talk about. When I ran Niche Tools (I sold it to make ends meet), I used to do a series.

It was good because it did three things well:

  • It was in my niche (Niche Tools was a database of free tools you could build)
  • Engagement — to see the site, users had to engage with the post
  • Lots of sales

It worked. It got people to comment. I would DM the link of the site, share it, and get anywhere from 2-5 signups each time. I sent it three times a week.

That was my only marketing.

So when you build something, make sure you are always marketing. I found something that worked and repeated it in a different format, which allowed me to grow that database tremendously.

So what am I trying to say?

It's simple: don’t stop trying. If you fail, it’s ok—there will be another opportunity. And find a good marketing strategy. Test everything.

You are a seller. You need to get the user to buy. The only way to do that is to market. Keep going.

title: 2 Keys to Keeping Newsletter Subscribers (The TLDR Formula)
content:
I’m not claiming to be a retention genius, but after thirty-plus issues I’ve learned a few things about keeping subscribers reading.

1. Nail the subject line.

Yes, it sounds obvious. It’s still 90% of the game. Write the email first, then pick a line that teases the core promise in two or three words. Curiosity beats clever every time.

2. Earn every scroll.

Most people won’t read to the end, so front-load the value. Hook them in the first paragraph the way YouTubers hook viewers—tell them what they’ll get if they keep going.

Make the writing easy to skim. Short paragraphs. Clear transitions. No fluff. Social feeds trained everyone to process information in seconds, so respect the pace.

That’s why TLDR thrives. Three sections, two items in each, one punchy summary per link. Simple, predictable, useful.

People don’t read TLDR because they’ve never seen the news—it’s because the summaries hit faster than the original articles. That’s the bar. Be different, be concise, and give them a reason to stay subscribed.

title: Life Is Hard.. But you keep going

title: The Art of Blogging: 10% Human is Still King
content:
To write a good blog post takes time. AI can help you in the research department but you really need to put your own spin on stuff to get anything that will attract users, rank on google and do well for your blog, post or whatever you are working on.

How do I know this? I was a blogger back in the day...nothing special I did it in crazy simple niches that no one knew about but it's where I made my first internet money.

The blog was simple.... it was right when twitch and other sites were taking off and this concept of "streaming" video games was a thing.

The blog? Help you become a better stream... my best article was Best Streaming PC's and I'd link to top Products on amazon. I was getting 4% and killing it with 100's of users coming to my site daily. With some of these products selling for $1,000+ I was making decent money.

Then it all came down.. I stopped caring about the blog (typical me) and start focusing on another blog, the content got old and big players like forbes, toms hardware and others starting seeing the trend. They built out fully detailed articles with actual reviews (they bought the products as well). That was my first taste of ranking on google. I was hooked.

Now while writing is easier because the ideas come faster, the highlights / overviews are easier to get. You still need to story tell and keep the reader in but also allow them to skim if they want. I don't have stats on it but my guess is 90% read the article till they see a highlight or "top" items. That's why lists up top or table of contents have become so popular.

Now every AI wrapper is trying to help you write blog posts. The artform is dying to just AI generate slop.

I still think if you do 90% AI and even as little as 10% human. You will rank on top of google.

So what should you do? **Start blogging.** If you don't wanna own it medium is a good platform and I've commited to writing daily on there and share results.

title: "Sell Me This Pen": 5 Ways to Close the Sale

  • **Give yourself 3-6 months.** As someone who product jumped a lot and looking back on it now that I'm writing this newsletter everyday. I wish I focused on things for longer. Built a legit product then worried about expanding it.

  • **Don't get hurt if they say no.** Rejection happens you can google all those stats that say 1 in 100 or 3% of people don't buy on the first time etc. You have to sell someone 7 times before they will buy. They will buy it or subscribe if you do it right and are in their circle.

So what should you be doing. You should be posting more on socials... adding more pSEO content to your site. Use free tools to build your brand aweareness. That's what I did with niche tools.
